column1: The Gibraltar national football team represents Gibraltar in international football competitions
column2: and is controlled by the Gibraltar Football Association. Gibraltar applied for full UEFA membership and was accepted by the UEFA Congress in May 2013 and can therefore compete in the UEFA European Championship beginning with the 2016 tournament for which the team competed in UEFA Euro 2016 qualifying Group D. On 13 May 2016 Gibraltar became a member of FIFA at the governing body's 66th Congress which was held in Mexico City. Gibraltar is the smallest UEFA member in terms of both area and population.Despite not being an island
column3: Gibraltar set up its first official side for the football competition at the 1993 Island Games and has been a regular in the tournament

column1: Gibraltar's first unofficial national match took place against Jersey in the 1993 Island Games in the Isle of Wight
column2: although the team had previously played friendlies versus professional and amateur clubs. The result was a 2–1 loss for the Gibraltarians. Gibraltar's largest unofficial win was 19–0 versus Sark
column5: whilst their largest unofficial loss was 5–0 versus Greenland – an autonomous region of Denmark – which also took part on the Isle of Wight

column1: The history of the Gibraltarian national football side can be traced back to April 1923
column2: when it travelled to Spain to play club side Sevilla in a friendly; two games were played and Gibraltar lost both. The side also managed a draw with Real Madrid in 1949.
Gibraltar competed in numerous football competitions
column3: most regularly in the Island Games.

column1: The first competition the team entered was the 1993 Island Games
column2: despite Gibraltar not being an island. Gibraltar lost all of its matches
column3: scoring only one goal and finishing in last place.

column1: They had much more success in the 1995 Island Games

column3: Gibraltar bounced back to record their first competitive win

column5: ahead of Anglesey only on goal difference
column6: and qualify for the semi finals. There
column8: before losing the final to the Isle of Wight by the same scoreline.

column1: After becoming a member of UEFA (see below)
column2: the GFA aimed to become a full FIFA member in time to participate in 2018 FIFA World Cup qualification. On 26 September 2014
column3: it was announced that Gibraltar's application for FIFA membership was denied
column4: with president Sepp Blatter stating that Gibraltar is ineligible because it is not an independent country. This was despite FIFA at the time including 22 members that are not independent countries
column5: including five in UEFA (Faroe Islands and the four Home Nations of the United Kingdom).  The Gibraltar Football Association then announced that it planned to appeal to the Court of Arbitration for Sport
column6: the same process by which Gibraltar successfully gained UEFA membership in 2013. The CAS heard Gibraltar's case on 21 May 2015
column7: at which time no time frame for a verdict was announced and further legal arguments would still be heard. It was expected that no decision would be reached before the FIFA congress coming the following week. A ruling was announced on 2 May 2016
column8: nearly a year after the CAS heard Gibraltar's case. As part of the ruling
column9: FIFA was ordered to transmit Gibraltar's application for membership to the FIFA congress which was set to take place the following week in Mexico City. Additionally
column10: FIFA was ordered to take "all necessary steps to admit the Gibraltar Football Association as a full member of FIFA without delay." If the vote held at the congress was successful
column11: it was believed that Gibraltar would be a last-minute addition to 2018 FIFA World Cup qualification. In FIFA's official statement regarding the ruling
column12: the organization said that the it expected to discuss the matter at the upcoming congress and discuss a course of action
column13: including potentially altering the congress agenda to submit Gibraltar's application for membership. On 13 May 2016
column14: Gibraltar was accepted as a member of FIFA with a vote of 172 to 12 in favour. Gibraltar became FIFA's 211th member immediately after the Football Federation of Kosovo was voted member 210.

column1: Gibraltar first applied for UEFA membership in 1999 but was rejected because of intense opposition from Spain.  Spain's opposition stemmed not only from claiming ownership of the territory but from fear that Gibraltar's acceptance would set a precedent that would inspire the separatist Basque national football team and Catalan national football teams to apply for UEFA membership as well. The issue was voted on again in 2007 but only three member nations (England
column2: Scotland
column3: and Wales) supported Gibraltar's bid after Spain threatened to withdraw Spanish teams from all UEFA competitions. UEFA then established rules
column4: which were introduced following pressure from Spain
column5: restricting membership to sovereign states recognised as such by the United Nations. The Gibraltar FA then went to the Court of Arbitration for Sport in 2007 and again in 2011 after an appeal and it was ruled that Gibraltar could not be refused membership because the sovereignty rules were not established until after Gibraltar's 1999 and 2007 applications.  At this time
column6: Gibraltar was named a provisional member of UEFA and was granted permission to enter national teams in under-17 and under-19 tournaments for the first time.The GFA was accepted as a full UEFA member by resolution of the UEFA Congress held in London on 24 May 2013
column7: with only Spain and Belarus opposed. This meant Gibraltar became the smallest UEFA member by population
column9: then Liechtenstein and the Faroe Islands. As a result of the vote
column10: the Gibraltar national team became eligible to enter the qualification tournaments for UEFA's premier national team competition
column11: the European Championship. The first such opportunity was the Euro 2016 qualifying campaign
column12: which would kick off in September 2014. Following the examples of Armenia–Azerbaijan and Russia–Georgia
column13: it was confirmed that Gibraltar and Spain would be kept apart in qualifying groups.After being accepted into UEFA
column14: the GFA outlined adjusted eligibility criteria for the selection of players for the national squad. To be eligible
column15: a player must be a British passport holder who was born in Gibraltar
column16: or has Gibraltarian parents or grandparents
column17: or has attended school for five years locally. Former Manchester United
column19: Southampton and Stoke City defender Danny Higginbotham
column20: whose uncle Allen Bula was the team manager
column21: was eligible to be called up because of this criteria adjustment. On 18 September 2013
column22: Higginbotham announced that he agreed in "principle" to play for Gibraltar. Recruiting of English-born players by manager Allen Bula was unpopular with some fans
column23: and in 2015 Bula's successor Jeff Wood said he would use more home-based players and develop local talent while still searching for eligible players elsewhere.Gibraltar's first official international match was a 0–0 friendly draw against Slovakia
column24: on 19 November 2013 at the Estadio Algarve in Portugal. On 23 February 2014
column25: Gibraltar was drawn in Group D for the UEFA Euro 2016 qualifying alongside Germany
column28: Republic of Ireland and Scotland. Initially
column29: Gibraltar were drawn into the same group as Spain for the tournament but the previous decision to keep the two teams apart in qualifying rounds was upheld and Gibraltar was immediately moved into another group. This was their first time participating in an official European competition.

column2: Gibraltar recorded their first ever victory under UEFA with a 1–0 win against Malta
column3: the goal coming from Kyle Casciaro.

column2: Gibraltar played their first competitive match – a Euro 2016 qualifier against Poland. Despite coming into the game with optimism and excitement
column3: they were still massive underdogs and although the half time score was only 1–0 to Poland
column5: they were defeated once again by 7–0
column6: this time by Republic of Ireland
column7: in their second Euro 2016 qualifier. In their third match
column8: they were beaten for the third time by Georgia 3–0.

column2: Gibraltar scored their first ever goal in a full international competitive match. Lee Casciaro scored against Scotland at Hampden Park
column3: Glasgow during the first half to level the match at 1–1. However
column4: Scotland went on to win 6–1. In July 2015
column5: Englishman Jeff Wood was appointed manager
column6: succeeding caretaker Dave Wilson who took over from Gibraltar's first manager Allen Bula in March 2015. Gibraltar could not repeat their performance of scoring a goal in the next two matches; losing 7–0 away against Germany and 4–0 against Republic of Ireland. On 7 September 2015
column7: Jake Gosling scored Gibraltar's second-ever competitive goal; netting a late consolation goal as his team was defeated 8–1 by Poland. Gibraltar finished its maiden qualifying campaign last in its group with zero points. With a 0–6 defeat to Scotland in the final match of qualifying
column8: Gibraltar allowed 56 total goals throughout qualification
column9: surpassing San Marino's previous record of 53 in a 10-match qualification process.

column2: the team played its home games at Victoria Stadium
column4: 000-seat national stadium of Gibraltar. There were plans to replace the stadium with a proposed 8
column6: which was expected to be completed for UEFA Euro 2016 qualifying. Due to the lack of suitable facilities in Gibraltar
column7: the team played its competitive home matches at Estádio Algarve about four hours away in Portugal
column8: from 2013 until 2018. Former national team manager Allen Bula stated that the team would play at the stadium for "a few years" until the Europa Point Stadium was complete. Although the Victoria Stadium could not be used for qualifying matches
column9: UEFA allowed its use for friendlies when Gibraltar chose to do so.In December 2014 the GFA applied for an exemption from UEFA to allow for competitive matches to be held at the Victoria Stadium although it did not meet minimum requirements. The exemption was filed based upon UEFA regulations which allow for an exemption to be granted because of "hardship". At that time
column10: UEFA said that all scheduled matches
column11: such as those during Euro 2016 qualification
column12: would take place in the already-determined locations but a determination would be made for future competitions. In February 2016 the Gibraltar government announced that over the previous four years numerous improvements had been made to the Victoria Stadium including the installation of approved AstroTurf and lighting which surpassed the requirements for a Category 2 stadium but did not quite meet Category 3. These improvements allowed for UEFA Champions League and Europa League matches to be played at the stadium.In September 2015
column13: after plans for Europa Point were abandoned
column14: the GFA explored other sites including Lathbury Barracks
column15: as UEFA were unwilling at the time to fund improvements to Victoria Stadium while it was government owned. In February 2016 the Government of Gibraltar announced that it expected to be presented for plans at the Lathbury site very soon. However
column16: in 2017 a deal was agreed for the Gibraltar FA to purchase Victoria Stadium with UEFA funding
column17: and re-develop the stadium to meet UEFA standards. The stadium was subsequently approved to host UEFA Euro 2020 qualifying games in March 2020
